title: Poetry x Class Reading Group: The Master’s Tools with Andrew McMillan
summary: What does an authentic poetry of working-class ‘work’ look like? If ‘work’ is often defined by the parameters of the employer, and pushed down onto the employee, then what power does poetry have to rename and reframe the notions of ‘work’, and how far can this be seen as a reclamation of power? Are questions like that a bit wanky? Does any of it matter? In this reading group session, I’m interested in considering the approaches different poets have taken…

title: Launch: MINOR DETAIL by Abania Shibli: Fitzcarraldo Editions
summary: Join us for the launch of brand new Fitzcarraldo title MINOR DETAIL by Adania Shibli - this is the publisher's first ever Arabic-language author. The book was originally published by al-Adab in 2017 and centers around a crime committed in the Palestinian Negev in August, 1949. Decades later, a young woman in Ramallah becomes obsessed with the events surrounding the crime. It is “an intricately layered and devastating work of fiction.” Don't miss this event with discussion and a reading…

title: Feminist Book Fortnight - Sophie Mackintosh and Avni Doshi in Conversation with Octavia Bright
summary: Join us as we welcome Sophie Mackintosh and Avni Doshi to read from and discuss their new novels, BLUE TICKET and BURNT SUGAR, with Literary Friction's Octavia Bright.  Find out more »

title: Niven Govinden and Paul Mendez in Conversation with Sophia Blackwell
summary: Join us as we welcome Niven Govinden and Paul Mendez discussing their novels, THIS BRUTAL HOUSE, and RAINBOW MILK, with Sophia Blackwell.  Find out more »

title: Trans Power: Juno Roche in Conversation with Meg-John Barker
summary: Join us as we welcome Juno Roche for a discussion of trans identities and gender empowerment with Meg-John Barker. Find out more »

title: Joelle Taylor, Bad Betty Poets + Open Mic Poetry Night
summary: A night of poetry with readings from Joelle Taylor (Outspoken Press) and three poets published by Bad Betty Press followed by open mic slots for female identifying poets. The first half of the night will showcase Joelle Taylor, Antonia Jade King, Charlotte Geater and Gita Ralleigh reading from their latest collections. The second half of the night will be over to you! We will have open mic slots of a maximum of five minutes per person for you to read and perform your own poems. Find out more »

title: Revolting Prostitutes: Juno Mac and Molly Smith with Shiri Shalmy
summary: Join us as we welcome Juno Mac and Molly Smith to celebrate the new paperback edition of REVOLTING PROSTITUTES. Find out more »

title: Feminism, Interrupted: Lola Olufemi in Conversation with Amelia Horgan
summary: Join us we welcome Lola Olufemi to discuss her new book, FEMINISM, INTERRUPTED, with Amelia Horgan. The book is the latest in the Outspoken series from Pluto Press. Find out more »

title: Alone/Together – Imaginary Millions at Libreria
summary: In light of recent COVID-19 developments, this event has been postponed until further notice. All tickets will be refunded. The team at Libreria thanks you for your understanding.Join us for an intimate night listening to two amazing artists as they showcase individual sets, before jamming out together; creating a performance never seen or heard before. As always, the question we ask is simply ‘What’s Possible From Here?’.

title: Box Hill: Adam Mars-Jones and Richard Scott
summary: Novelist, essayist, memoirist and book and film reviewer Adam Mars-Jones will be at the shop to read from and talk about his latest book Box Hill (Fitzcarraldo). On his eighteenth birthday Colin, taking a walk on the eponymous Surrey hillside, stumbles across Ray, part of the biker community centred on Box Hill. Mars-Jones recounts the love story between the two men in his continuing exploration of the dynamics of desire and domination. ‘It is’ writes Margaret Drabble, ‘a characteristic Mars-Jones mixture of the shocking, the endearing, the funny and the sad, with an unforgettable narrator.’ Adam Mars-Jones will be in conversation with Richard Scott, author of the poetry collection Soho.

title: The Discomfort of Evening: Marieke Lucas Rijneveld & Sophie Collins
summary: Marieke Lucas Rijneveld rose to fame in their native Netherlands with their first poetry collection Calfskin. This early success is now followed by a novel The Discomfort of Evening (Faber), a portrait of a Dutch farming family torn apart by grief, already a huge bestseller in the Netherlands and now available in English in a translation by Michele Hutchison. Rijneveld will be reading from their work and will be in conversation with the artist and poet Sophie Collins, (Small White Monkeys; Who is Mary Sue?) who was herself born and brought up in North Holland.Part of New Dutch Writing, presented by the Dutch Foundation for Literature.

title: LRB Screen: Christina Newland presents American Gigolo
Little Eyes: Samanta Schweblin & Chris Power
summary: Argentinian writer Samanta Schweblin’s fictions, both in short and long form (A Mouthful of Birds; Fever Dream) are consistently unsettling in the way they mix the familiar and the surreal, conveying an off-centre perspective on the world we think we know. Her latest novel Little Eyes (One World, translated by Megan McDowell) explores issues of surveillance, voyeurism and connectivity through the medium of the Kentuki, an apparently benign amalgam of toy, mobile phone, camera and robot that is taking the world by storm, but which has, it transpires, increasingly sinister implications.Schweblin will be in conversation about her work with Chris Power, author of the short story collection Mothers.This event is supported by The Embassy of Argentina and Cervantes Institute.

title: April Late Shopping Evening
summary: Join us for our monthly Late Shopping Evening. Reserve your place and enjoy a 10% discount on all books, recommendations from our expert booksellers and a glass of wine to sip whilst you browse the shelves, plus seasonal treats from the Cake Shop – details to be announced soon, so watch this space!

title: Recollections of My Non-Existence: Rebecca Solnit & Mary Beard
summary: Beginning in San Francisco in 1981, the era of punk and nascent gay pride, Rebecca Solnit’s latest book Recollections of My Non-Existence (Granta) is a powerful memoir of growing both as a woman and an artist, drawing on the powers of literature, activism and solidarity in the face of an apparently unbreachable patriarchy. The struggle to find a voice and to find a way to make that voice heard are brilliantly captured and dissected by one of feminism’s, and indeed the world’s, foremost thinkers.Rebecca Solnit will be in conversation about her life and work with historian Mary Beard, whose most recent book is Women & Power: A Manifesto. Both of our speakers are regular contributors to the pages of the LRB.This event is in partnership with 5x15Please note that this event will take place at the Emmanuel Centre.

title: You People: Nikita Lalwani & Tessa Hadley
summary: Nikita Lalwani’s latest novel You People (Viking) centres on a London pizzeria where the chefs are Sri Lankan and many of the kitchen staff are illegal immigrants. Through a diverse set of characters Lalwani draws a vivid portrait of contemporary British life as it really is lived.Lalwani will be in conversation about her work with writer and teacher Tessa Hadley, who has described You People as being ‘Enthralling as a thriller, yet also a beautiful human drama, and a serious enquiry into the possibility of goodness.’

title: Greenery: Tim Dee & Julia Blackburn
summary: In his latest book Greenery (Cape) ornithologist and environmental writer Tim Dee travels in search of spring, from South Africa via Chad and the Sahara to Spain and northern Europe. Always alert to the sounds, sights and smells of nature, his observations are throughout informed by poetry – in what used to be his day job, Tim Dee was a Radio 4 producer, most notably on the long-running poetry requests programme Poetry, Please!  Dee will be in conversation about his travels with the writer Julia Blackburn, whose many books have covered topics as diverse as Billie Holiday, the Tuscan countryside, the Norfolk artist John Craske, Goya and most recently in Time Song the lost continent of Doggerland.

title: Feminism, Interrupted: Lola Olufemi & Momtaza Mehri
summary: Black feminist writer, organiser and activist Lola Olufemi will be in conversation about her book Feminism, Interrupted: Disrupting Power (Pluto). As feminism enters the mainstream of political thought and social action, is it in danger of being diluted? Olufemi argues the case for a radical feminism, divorced from consumerism and the state, which might become a liberating force for people of all genders and of none.She will be discussing her work with poet and essayist Momtaza Mehri.

title: Slowdown: Danny Dorling & Zoe Williams
summary: In his intriguing and counterintuitive new book Slowdown (Yale) Danny Dorling argues that, contrary to what most of us believe, human life is actually slowing down, in diverse areas from birth rate to GDP to technological innovation. And, what’s more, in an arresting graphic style combining text and data with illustrations by Kirsten McClure, he shows how slowing down can be good for the planet, for the economy and for our lives in general.Professor Dorling will be presenting his evidence in conversation with the Guardian’s Zoe Williams.

title: Funny Weather: Olivia Laing & Emily LaBarge
summary: Jean-Michel Basquiat, Georgia O'Keefe, Hilary Mantel, Ali Smith, David Bowie and Freddie Mercury all feature in Olivia Laing’s latest essay collection Funny Weather (Picador). In the current inclement political climate, Laing argues, art and artists matter more than ever, as a locus for both political resistance and emotional repair. ‘Like all great critics’ James Lasdun writes, ‘Olivia Laing combines formidable intelligence with boundless curiosity and fabulous taste, but she also has a rare quality of intimacy; an ability to connect the reader to a work of art or literature (or for that matter a facet of life itself) with a directness that lights it up like nothing else.’Olivia Laing will be arguing the case for the necessity of art with Emily LaBarge, a writer and teacher at the Royal College of Art whose work has appeared in the White Review, the Guardian and Tate Etc.

title: Blue Ticket: Sophie Mackintosh and Rachael Allen
summary: Sophie Mackintosh’s second novel Blue Ticket (Hamish Hamilton), following her Booker longlisted debut The Water Cure, is a subversive fable exploring fate, free will and motherhood. ‘The cool intensity and strange beauty of Blue Ticket is a wonder’, writes Deborah Levy, ‘Be sure to read everything Sophie Mackintosh writes’.Mackintosh will be in conversation about her work with the poet Rachael Allen.

title: May Late Shopping Evening
Seán Hewitt & Andrew McMillan
summary: Seán Hewitt’s Tongues of Fire (Cape) is one of the most eagerly-awaited debut poetry collections of 2020; Fiona Benson has described Hewitt’s poetry as ‘beyond-gorgeous, beyond-glorious, blood-felt, feral, luminous.’Hewitt will be reading from Tongues of Fire and in conversation with Andrew McMillan, whose most recent collection playtime (Cape) won the Polari Prize 2019.

title: Cleanness: Garth Greenwell & Tash Aw
summary: Garth Greenwell’s first book What Belongs to You was hailed as ‘an instant classic’ by the New York Times for its lyrical exploration of gay desire and longing. Its sequel Cleanness (Picador) revisits Sofia, the location of What Belongs to You, and has been described by writer Eimear McBride as ‘An unbearably wonderful, eloquently sexual, thoughtful, emotional delight of a novel’.Greenwell will be reading from his work, and discussing it with the novelist Tash Aw.

title: Sinews of War and Trade: Laleh Khalili & Rafeef Ziadah
summary: In Sinews of War and Trade (Verso) Laleh Khalili, professor of politics and international studies at SOAS, University of London, explores the vital importance of ports and shipping in defining the new battlegrounds of the 21st century. In particular, she argues, the Arabian Peninsula is the crucial nexus for the transportation of the goods and commodities that define and enable contemporary capitalism, inevitably making it a region of compelling strategic importance and of military and diplomatic conflict.She will be in conversation about her book with Dr Rafeef Ziadah, who is conducting research on the commerce and politics of the Gulf region at SOAS.

title: June Late Shopping Evening
summary: Join us for our monthly Late Shopping Evening. Reserve your place and enjoy a 10% discount on all books, recommendations from our expert booksellers and a glass of wine to sip whilst you browse the shelves, plus seasonal treats from the Cake Shop – details to be announced soon, so watch this space!
